citeinfo.origin: North Carolina Division of Coastal Management
citeinfo.title: AEC - Inlet Hazard Areas - Boundary

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.4000

descript.abstract: The prime objective of the agreement between teh Division of Marine Fisheries and the Coastal Resources Commission was as follows: "Develop and apply a Coastal Resource Commission approved method for identification and delineation of hazard areas adjacent to existing inlets for use by the Commission in designating Inlet Lands Area of Environmental Concern (AEC) in the vicinity of inlets."
descript.purpose: Develop and apply a Coastal Resource Commission approved method for identification and delineation of hazard areas adjacent to existing inlets for use by the Commission in designating Inlet Lands Area of Environmental Concern (AEC) in the vicinity of inlets.

theme.themekt: REQUIRED: Reference to a formally registered thesaurus or a similar authoritative source of theme keywords.

idinfo.useconst: Use of these data is permitted without consent from the NC Division of Coastal Management. These data should not be used for navigational purposes.

cntorgp.cntorg: North Carolina Division of Coastal Management

idinfo.datacred: North Carolina Division of Coastal Management

procstep.procdesc: IHA boundaries were digitized from paper maps in 2002

cntorgp.cntorg: North Carolina Division of Coastal Management

citeinfo.origin: North Carolina Division of Coastal Management
citeinfo.title: Inlet Hazard Areas: The Final Report and Recommendations

srcinfo.srcscale: North Carolina Division of Coastal Management

dataqual.logic:
When these boundaries were delineated, GIS technology was not available. At the time of the study, all commercially available photography that met scale and coverage requirements and was readily obtainable was catalogued by the Division of Marine Fisheries (DMF). In addition, photography taken by DMF, National Ocean Survey, US Dept. of Agriculture, and NC DOT was also used.
SCALING: A geographically stationary control system was established for each inlet or inlet complex so that an accurate scale for photograph could be established. Absolute scales were independently compared to the1977 NC DOT photo-base blue prints. The results were so consistently accurate on four inlets tested that the 1977 DOT scaled (1"=400') photography was accepted as the base control.
GRIDDING: Using the scale of 1"=400" in conjunction with identifiable photo-points, a geographically stationary grid system in the vicinity of each inlet complex was established. The grid was oriented parallel to the predominant ocean shoreline. A grid spacing of 300 feet was selected as to provide adequate resolution of an inlet's gyrations.
STATISTICS: The left and right sides of each inlet were treated separately and individual inlet grids were regressed both linearly and quadraticaliy to determine the best fit trends of the inlet. On accepted curve fits, the landwardmost 99% confidence interval projected to occur between 1978 and 1988 on a given grid was made to represent the limit of the inlet hazard area'on that grid. A few inlets displayed apparent higher degree or complex transcendental movement, so some fits were rejected on these inlets for other methods. Due to the narrow forty year X-field of the data, some quadratic fits on shorelines showing wide short-term excursions had to be rejected as meaningless. Multiple throats, channel stabilization projects, and shoreline stabilization projects frequently interfere with the regression process, and some fits were rejected because of the existence of one or more of these.
OTHER METHODS: When inlets or grids did not conform to attempted regression methods, strong emphasis was placed on previous inlet territory, as determined by relict inlet ridge locations. The methods used are described by John J. Fisher in his two papers, "Geomorphic Expression of Former Inlets Along the Outer Banks of North Carolina," 1962, and "Development Patterns of Relict Beach Ridges, Outer Banks Barrier Chain, North Carolina," 1967. Documented historic locations, and structurally weak areas near the inlet were also considered in determination of the limits of the hazard areas.
